**Joseph "Kaka" Baptista** (17 March 1864 – 1930) was an Indian politician and
activist from [Bombay](/wiki/Bombay "Bombay") (today known as Mumbai), closely
associated with the [Lokmanya Tilak](/wiki/Lokmanya_Tilak "Lokmanya Tilak")
and the [Home Rule Movement](/wiki/Home_Rule_Movement "Home Rule Movement").
He is credited with the coining of the popular phrase "Swaraj is my Birthright
and I shall have it".[1] He was elected as the [Mayor of
Bombay](/wiki/Mayor_of_Mumbai "Mayor of Mumbai") in 1925. He was given the
title _Kaka_ that means "uncle".

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Joseph_Baptista&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life")]

Joseph Baptista was born on 17 March 1864 in Matharpacady in
[Mazagaon](/wiki/Mazagaon "Mazagaon"), Bombay. His father, John Baptista
hailed from [Uttan](/wiki/Uttan "Uttan"), near [Bassein](/wiki/Vasai "Vasai")
(now Vasai). The Baptistas belonged to the [East Indian](/wiki/East_Indians
"East Indians") ethnic community, who were converted to [Roman
Catholicism](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") during Portuguese rule
between the sixteenth and eighteenth centuries.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

He completed his early education from [St. Mary's School,
Mumbai](/wiki/St._Mary%27s_School,_Mumbai "St. Mary's School, Mumbai"). He
then joined the [College of Engineering](/wiki/College_of_Engineering,_Pune
"College of Engineering, Pune") in [Pune](/wiki/Pune "Pune") and later pursued
a BA degree in [Political Science](/wiki/Political_Science "Political
Science") from the [Fitzwilliam College,
Cambridge](/wiki/Fitzwilliam_College,_Cambridge "Fitzwilliam College,
Cambridge").[2] During this period, he first met [Bal Gangadhar
Tilak](/wiki/Bal_Gangadhar_Tilak "Bal Gangadhar Tilak").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Political
activism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Joseph_Baptista&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Political activism")]

In 1901, Baptista joined the [Bombay Municipal
Corporation](/wiki/Bombay_Municipal_Corporation "Bombay Municipal
Corporation"), and would be a part of the BMC for the next 17 years.
Influenced by the [Irish Home Rule](/wiki/Irish_Home_Rule "Irish Home Rule")
movement, Baptista's ideas on an Indian version took root. His ideas deeply
influenced Tilak and the two became close associates. He assisted Tilak by
launching the _Sarvajanik Ganpati_ (public Ganpati celebrations) to raise
nationalistic feelings.[1] In addition, Baptista coined the phrase "Swaraj is
my Birthright", that was later made popular by Tilak.[1] In 1916, along with
Tilak, [Annie Besant](/wiki/Annie_Besant "Annie Besant") founded the Home Rule
Movement, with Baptista opening the [Belgaum](/wiki/Belgaum "Belgaum")
unit.[1] He was also the legal advisor to Lokmanya Tilak.[3] Later he
interviewed British Prime Minister [David Lloyd
George](/wiki/David_Lloyd_George "David Lloyd George") for the British
government's views on the Home Rule. In the interview, Baptista gained the
impression "that the Cabinet had decided to give India the fullest possible
measure of Home Rule without delay."[4]

Baptista was also a practising barrister at the [Bombay High
Court](/wiki/Bombay_High_Court "Bombay High Court"). One of his most high-
profile clients was [Vinayak Damodar Savarkar](/wiki/Vinayak_Damodar_Savarkar
"Vinayak Damodar Savarkar"), where he demanded an open trial to assure the
dignity of fundamental rights.[1] In 1920, founded the [All India Trade Union
Congress](/wiki/All_India_Trade_Union_Congress "All India Trade Union
Congress") (AITUC). As a labour leader he took up the cause of mill workers
and postmen and other blue collar workers. Although religious, he refused to
mix politics and religion refusing to have separate religion-based
electorates.[1]

> I thoroughly disapprove of separate electorate for Indian Christians in
> water-tight compartments

In 1925, Baptista was elected as the [Mayor](/wiki/Mayor_of_Mumbai "Mayor of
Mumbai") of the [Bombay Municipal
Corporation](/wiki/Bombay_Municipal_Corporation "Bombay Municipal
Corporation"), a post that he occupied for a year.[1]

## Death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Joseph_Baptista&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Death")]

Baptista died in 1930 and is buried in the [Sewri
cemetery](/wiki/Sewri_cemetery "Sewri cemetery"). The [Mazagon
Gardens](/wiki/Mazagon_Gardens "Mazagon Gardens"), site of the demolished
[Mazagaon Fort](/wiki/Mazagaon_Fort "Mazagaon Fort"), near [Dockyard
Road](/wiki/Dockyard_Road "Dockyard Road") station is named after him. On 12
October 2008, his tomb at [Sewri cemetery](/wiki/Sewri_cemetery "Sewri
cemetery") was restored with the funds of local
[MLC](/wiki/Member_of_the_Legislative_Council_\(India\) "Member of the
Legislative Council \(India\)") Kapil Patil. The ceremony was attended by
members of the [Bombay Catholic Sabha](/wiki/Bombay_Catholic_Sabha "Bombay
Catholic Sabha") and Shikshak Bharati, a teacher's organisation.[5]

In 1999, a book on Baptista titled _Joseph Baptista: The father of Home Rule
in India_ was released by K R Shirsat at [Lalbaug](/wiki/Lalbaug "Lalbaug") in
Mumbai. Through the book, the author hoped that Baptista would be a role model
for modern-day youths.[6]
